terms.definition: Type of heart attack caused by complete blockage of a coronary artery, characterized by ST-segment elevation on ECG. Requires immediate reperfusion therapy (PCI or thrombolysis within 90 minutes).

translations.es: Infarto de miocardio con elevación del segmento ST
translations.fr: Infarctus du myocarde avec élévation du segment ST
translations.pt: Infarto do miocárdio com elevação do segmento ST
translations.it: Infarto miocardico con sopraslivellamento del tratto ST
translations.ar: احتشاء عضلة القلب مع ارتفاع المقطع ST

terms.clinical_pearls: Door-to-balloon time <90 minutes is critical. Give aspirin, clopidogrel, heparin immediately.
terms.example_usage: The patient presented with chest pain and ECG showed ST-elevation in leads V2-V4, consistent with anterior STEMI.

terms.definition: Type of heart attack without ST-segment elevation on ECG, but with elevated cardiac biomarkers (troponin). Partial coronary artery occlusion. Managed with antiplatelet therapy and early coronary angiography (within 24-72 hours).

translations.es: Infarto de miocardio sin elevación del segmento ST
translations.fr: Infarctus du myocarde sans élévation du segment ST
translations.pt: Infarto do miocárdio sem elevação do segmento ST
translations.it: Infarto miocardico senza sopraslivellamento del tratto ST
translations.ar: احتشاء عضلة القلب بدون ارتفاع المقطع ST

terms.clinical_pearls: GRACE score helps risk stratification. High-risk patients need angiography within 24 hours.
terms.example_usage: Troponin elevated to 2.5 ng/mL without ST changes, diagnosed as NSTEMI. GRACE score 140 (high risk).

terms.definition: Heart attack resulting from coronary artery occlusion leading to myocardial cell death. Diagnosed by cardiac biomarkers (troponin) and ECG changes. Classified as STEMI or NSTEMI.
terms.clinical_pearls: Troponin is the gold standard biomarker. Serial measurements increase sensitivity.
terms.example_usage: Patient had classic MI symptoms: crushing chest pain, diaphoresis, and dyspnea.

terms.definition: Spectrum of conditions caused by acute myocardial ischemia, including unstable angina, NSTEMI, and STEMI. Requires immediate evaluation with ECG, troponin, and risk stratification.
terms.clinical_pearls: HEART score helps risk-stratify chest pain patients in ED. Score >3 warrants admission.
terms.example_usage: Patient presented with ACS features: chest pain at rest, positive troponin, new T-wave inversions.

terms.definition: Minimally invasive procedure to open blocked coronary arteries using balloon angioplasty and stent placement. Primary treatment for STEMI (door-to-balloon <90 minutes).

translations.zh: 经皮冠状动脉介入治疗
translations.ja: 経皮的冠動脈インターベンション

terms.clinical_pearls: Radial access reduces bleeding complications vs femoral. DAPT for 12 months post-stent.
terms.example_usage: Patient underwent primary PCI with drug-eluting stent placement to LAD.

terms.definition: Chest pain at rest or with minimal exertion without elevated cardiac biomarkers. Part of ACS spectrum. High risk for progression to MI. Requires antiplatelet therapy and early angiography.
terms.clinical_pearls: Distinguished from NSTEMI by negative troponin. May have reversible ECG changes.
terms.example_usage: Crescendo angina with pain at rest, troponin negative - diagnosed as unstable angina.

terms.definition: Small mesh tube placed in coronary artery to keep it open after angioplasty. Drug-eluting stents (DES) release medication to prevent restenosis. Requires dual antiplatelet therapy.
terms.clinical_pearls: DES preferred over bare-metal stents. DAPT duration: 12 months for elective, potentially longer for ACS.
terms.example_usage: Two drug-eluting stents were deployed in the RCA with good angiographic result.

terms.definition: Syndrome where the heart cannot pump enough blood to meet the body's needs. Causes fluid accumulation in lungs and periphery. Classified by ejection fraction (HFrEF vs HFpEF).
terms.clinical_pearls: NYHA classification guides severity. BNP/NT-proBNP helpful for diagnosis and prognosis.
terms.example_usage: Patient with CHF exacerbation presented with dyspnea, orthopnea, and bilateral leg edema.

terms.definition: Progressive lung disease characterized by airflow limitation. Includes emphysema and chronic bronchitis. Major risk factor: smoking. Diagnosed by spirometry (FEV1/FVC <0.70).
terms.clinical_pearls: GOLD classification guides therapy. Long-acting bronchodilators are first-line maintenance.
terms.example_usage: COPD exacerbation with increased dyspnea and purulent sputum. Spirometry shows FEV1 45% predicted.

terms.definition: Acute neurological deficit caused by interrupted blood flow to the brain. Ischemic (87%) or hemorrhagic (13%). tPA window: 4.5 hours for ischemic stroke.
terms.clinical_pearls: Time is brain - 1.9 million neurons die per minute. NIHSS score guides severity and treatment.
terms.example_usage: Patient with acute left hemiparesis and aphasia. CT negative for hemorrhage. tPA given at 3 hours.

terms.definition: Metabolic disorder characterized by hyperglycemia. Type 1 (autoimmune) or Type 2 (insulin resistance). Diagnosed by HbA1c ≥6.5%, fasting glucose ≥126 mg/dL, or OGTT ≥200 mg/dL.
terms.clinical_pearls: Target HbA1c <7% for most patients. Screen for microvascular complications annually.
terms.example_usage: Newly diagnosed Type 2 DM with HbA1c 8.2%. Started on metformin and lifestyle modifications.

terms.definition: Progressive loss of kidney function over ≥3 months. Staged by GFR (G1-G5). Common causes: diabetes, hypertension. Complications: anemia, bone disease, cardiovascular disease.
terms.clinical_pearls: KDIGO guidelines for staging. ACE-I/ARB slow progression in proteinuric CKD.
terms.example_usage: CKD Stage 3b (GFR 35 mL/min) secondary to diabetic nephropathy. Anemia with Hgb 9.8 g/dL.

terms.definition: Blood clot in pulmonary arteries, often from DVT. Presents with dyspnea, chest pain, hemoptysis. Diagnosed by CTPA or V/Q scan. Treated with anticoagulation.
terms.clinical_pearls: PERC rule can exclude PE without D-dimer if low risk. Massive PE may need thrombolysis.
terms.example_usage: Sudden dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. Wells score 5. CTPA confirmed saddle PE.

terms.definition: Life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by dysregulated host response to infection. Defined by SOFA score ≥2. Requires early antibiotics and resuscitation (SEP-1 bundle).
terms.clinical_pearls: Hour-1 bundle: lactate, blood cultures, broad-spectrum antibiotics, fluid resuscitation.
terms.example_usage: Sepsis from pneumonia with SOFA score 4. Lactate 3.2 mmol/L. Started on ceftriaxone and azithromycin.

terms.definition: Most common arrhythmia characterized by irregular, rapid atrial activity. Increases stroke risk 5-fold. Managed with rate/rhythm control and anticoagulation based on CHA₂DS₂-VASc score.
terms.clinical_pearls: CHA₂DS₂-VASc ≥2 (men) or ≥3 (women) warrants anticoagulation. DOACs preferred over warfarin.
terms.example_usage: New-onset AFib with RVR (HR 145). CHA₂DS₂-VASc score 3 - started on apixaban and metoprolol.

terms.definition: End-stage liver disease with irreversible fibrosis and regenerative nodules. Common causes: alcohol, HCV, NAFLD. Complications: portal hypertension, ascites, hepatic encephalopathy, HCC.
terms.clinical_pearls: Child-Pugh and MELD scores predict prognosis. Screen for varices with EGD. HCC surveillance q6mo.
terms.example_usage: Decompensated cirrhosis with ascites, jaundice. MELD score 22 - listed for liver transplant.

terms.definition: Chronic condition where stomach acid flows back into esophagus causing heartburn and esophagitis. Risk factors: obesity, hiatal hernia, pregnancy. First-line treatment: PPI.
terms.clinical_pearls: Lifestyle modifications first. PPI trial for 8 weeks. Red flags warrant endoscopy.
terms.example_usage: Typical GERD symptoms: heartburn after meals, regurgitation. Started on omeprazole 20mg daily.

terms.definition: Chronic autoimmune inflammatory arthritis causing symmetric polyarthritis, joint erosions, and systemic manifestations. Diagnosed by clinical criteria, RF, anti-CCP antibodies.
terms.clinical_pearls: Treat to target: remission or low disease activity. Early DMARD therapy prevents erosions.
terms.example_usage: Seropositive RA with symmetric MCP/PIP joint swelling. RF+ and anti-CCP+. Started methotrexate.

terms.definition: Multisystem autoimmune disease with diverse manifestations: malar rash, photosensitivity, arthritis, nephritis, serositis. Diagnosed by ACR/EULAR criteria. ANA positive in >95%.

translations.ja: 全身性エリテマトーデス

terms.clinical_pearls: Hydroxychloroquine is cornerstone therapy. Monitor for lupus nephritis with UA and Cr.
terms.example_usage: SLE flare with malar rash, arthritis, proteinuria. ANA 1:640 speckled, anti-dsDNA elevated.
